div1.p: Hench wants to know when the documents he requested will be ready for his viewing.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to R.H. Brooke, September 2, 1941
div1.opener:
y.f.
September 2, 1941
Mr. R. H. Brooke, Chief Clerk
War Department
Office of the Surgeon General
Washington
S.G.O. 201 (Hench, P. S.)
My dear Mr. Brooke:
div1.p:
Thank you very kindly for sending me your enclosed
reply. I expect to attend a medical meeting in Washing-
ton in January. Do you imagine that you will be able to
arrange for the search for the material in the next few
weeks? I should of course much prefer to have copies of
the material for my permanent use here but if the material
cannot be searched for immediately I am indeed hoping that
it can be looked over so that at least when I come in Jan-
uary I will have the opportunity of seeing it and picking
out myself what I should like to have copied. I realize
that in these difficult times for the War Department such
a request as mine may seem out of place but after all we
must continue the pursuits of peace and if this request
does not interfere too greatly with your other duties I
shall certainly appreciate your continued cooperation.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
